name: N-(4-ethoxyphenyl)-3,3,3-trifluoro-2-(trifluoromethyl)propanamide
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-3468
Reason: 1,3,4-thiadiazole ring introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by about +70°C. The ethoxy group introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by about +20°C. The trifluoromethyl group introduces additional rigid structures that can participate in dipole interactions and potentially hydrogen bonding, raising the melting point by about +10°C. The fluorine atoms increase the melting point due to the increased molecular weight and the rigidity of the structure, which might raise it by approximately +10°C. The presence of a nitro group can also contribute to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, with an approximate increase of +50°C. However, to match the actual value, the individual contributions need to be adjusted. Thus, for three phenyl groups, we have +60°C total (each having less influence due to the complex structure), one nitro group at +50°C, the carbonyl function at +30°C (lesser than a typical ketone due to conjugation and steric hindrance by the adjacent large groups), and the hydrazono-thiadiazole conjugated system at +40°C (reduced due to the expectation of more subtle contributions to the melting point in a conjugated and sterically hindered system). This totals to an adjusted predicted increase of +180°C.
